Network traffic patterns consistent with.Action: Monitor Zeek http.log and conn.log for high-volume or unusual outbound traffic to common web services (Dropbox, Google Drive, etc.). Use descriptive statistics and IQR analysis on data volume and connection frequency per user/host to identify outliers indicative of exfiltration or high-frequency C2 communications disguised as normal web traffic.

Attempts to access internal resources us.Data: Windows Event ID 4624; Windows Event ID 4625; Zeek conn.log
Attempts to access internal resources us.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4624 and 4625 for login attempts. Correlate source IPs and account names with threat intelligence feeds or internal lists of potentially compromised accounts/IPs identified from external web service breaches. Use correlation analysis to identify patterns of failed/successful logins from suspicious sources or using suspicious accounts.

Suspicious internal host connections to.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek conn.log; Zeek ssl.log
Suspicious internal host connections to.Action: Monitor Zeek http.log, conn.log, and ssl.log for internal hosts communicating with external web services (e.g., cloud storage, code repositories). Correlate outbound requests with threat intelligence feeds for known malicious URLs or domains hosted on these services. Use frequency analysis on bytes transferred (Zeek conn.log, http.log) and unique destinations (Zeek conn.log) to identify hosts with unusual outbound data patterns or connection diversity to these services compared to peer groups.

Download or execution of uncommon file t.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek files.log; Windows Event ID 4688
Download or execution of uncommon file t.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log for file downloads from common external web services. Use Zeek files.log to inspect downloaded file types, especially executable code (.exe, .dll, scripts). Correlate download events (Zeek logs) with Windows Event ID 4688 on endpoints to identify execution of suspicious files originating from these downloads. Use correlation analysis to link specific downloads from web services to subsequent malicious process activity.
